revision.text:
{{Infobox software | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = Objectivity, Inc. | released = {{Start-date|2010}}<!-- see http://twitter.com/#!/infinitegraph/status/16889034183 --> | frequently updated = yes | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]], Core in [[C++]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | language = | genre = [[Graph database]] | license = Free (EULA), and [[commercial software|commercial]] | website = http://www.infinitegraph.com }}
'''InfiniteGraph''' is a distributed [[graph database]] <ref name="readwriteweb"> {{ cite web |url= http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/08/the-other-non-sql-alternative.php |title= The Other Non-SQL Alternative: Infinite Graph 2.0 |author= Scott M. Fulton, III |date= August 24, 2011 |work= ReadWriteWeb |publisher= ReadWriteWeb |accessdate= August 24, 2011 }} </ref> implemented in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], and is from a class of [[Nosql|NOSQL]] (or Not Only SQL) data technologies <ref name="siliconangle"> {{ cite web |url= http://siliconangle.com/blog/2011/08/16/infinitegraph-plays-nice-in-nosql-sandbox-launches-new-tool/ |title= InfiniteGraph Plays Nice in NoSQL Sandbox, Launches New Tool |author= Kristen Nicole |date= August 16, 2011 |work= SiliconANGLE |publisher= SiliconANGLE |accessdate= August 16, 2011 }} </ref> focused on [[Graph (data structure)|graph data structures]]. Graph data typically consist of objects or things (nodes) and various relationships (edges) that may connect two or more nodes. Developers may use Infinitegraph to build web and mobile applications and services that need to solve [[Graph theory|graph problems]] or answer questions that may include "How am I connected to [[Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon|Kevin Bacon]]?", "Where's the nearest Starbucks?" or "What are the cheapest non-stop, roundtrip flights I can get from California to New York, leaving at 8am Tuesday, and returning by 6pm Friday?".<ref name="techcrunch"> {{ cite web |url= http://techcrunch.com/2011/08/16/infinitegraph-steps-out-of-beta-to-help-companies-identify-deep-relationships-in-large-data-sets/ |title= InfiniteGraph Steps Out Of Beta To Help Companies Identify Deep Relationships In Large Data Sets |author= Rip Empson |date= August 16, 2011 |work= TechCrunch |publisher= AOL |accessdate= August 16, 2011 }} </ref>
==Technical specifications==
Here is an initial list of '''InfiniteGraph''' product specifications:
* API/Protocols: Java. (The next release (2.1) will support Tinkerpop, which provides REST, Frames, Gremlin, Ripple and Linked Process.) * Backup and Replication: Yes. * Concurrency: Update locking on subgraphs, concurrent non-blocking ingest. * Consistency: Flexible (from ACID to relaxed). * Distribution: Lock server and 64-bit object IDs support dynamic addressing space (with each federation capable of managing up to 65,356 individual databases and 10^24 bytes (one quadrillion gigabytes, or a yottabyte) of physical addressing space). * Graph Model: Labelled directed multigraph. * Language: Java (core C++). * License Options: Free (EULA), Commercial (usage or resource-based, perpetual or subscription options). * Platforms: Windows (32-bit and 64-bit), Linux (32-bit and 64-bit), Mac (64-bit). All are interoperable as well. * Processing: Multi-threaded. * Query Methods: Traverser and graph navigation API, predicate language qualification. * Schema: Supports schema-full and hybrid schema models. * Source: Proprietary, with open source extensions, integrated components and third party connectors. * Transactions: Fully Atomic.
'''InfiniteGraph''' is produced by Objectivity, Inc. - a company that develops data technologies supporting large-scale, distributed data management, object persistence and relationship analytics.<ref name="gigaom02"> {{ cite web |url= http://gigaom.com/cloud/twitters-success-pulls-23-year-old-objectivity-into-nosql/ |title= Twitterâ€™s Success Pulls 23-Year-Old Objectivity Into NoSQL |author= Derrick Harris |date= March 4, 2011 |work= GigaOM |publisher= GigaOM |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} </ref><ref name="morningstar"> {{ cite web |url= http://news.morningstar.com/all/business-wire/20110729005038/objectivity-inc-announces-record-revenues-for-its-final-quarter-of-fy11-growth-attributed-to-new-customer-deployments.aspx |title= Objectivity, Inc. Announces Record Revenues for its Final Quarter of FY11; Growth Attributed to New Customer Deployments |author= BusinessWire |date= July 29, 2011 |work= MorningStar |publisher= Morningstar, Inc. |accessdate= July 29, 2011 }} </ref><ref name="451group"> {{ cite web |url= http://www.the451group.com/report_view/report_view.php?entity_id=66355 |title= Objectivity identifies use cases for its InfiniteGraph graph database unit |author= Matt Aslett |date= February 9, 2011 |work= The 451 Group |publisher= The 451 Group |accessdate= February 9, 2011 }} </ref> '''InfiniteGraph''' was first released to the public in 2010 and the latest version (v.2.0) was made available in August 2011.<ref name="yahoo"> {{ cite web |url= http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Commercial-Release-iw-2655863238.html?x=0 |title= Commercial Release of InfiniteGraph(TM), the Leading Distributed and Scalable Graph Database, Is Now Available |author= MarketWire |date= August 16, 2011 |work= Finance.Yahoo.com |publisher= Yahoo! |accessdate= August 16, 2011 }} </ref> '''InfiniteGraph''' is currently available in both free and paid license versions.
{{Clear}}
